questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is true about simple random sampling?

options.a: It is the sampling method of choice for heterogenous population
options.b: Members are selected without specifying any criteria for selection
options.c: Every 5th or 10th member is picked at regular interval
options.d: Population is first divided into strata then sampled randomly

questions.explanation:
In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population 
has equal chances of being included. In other words, the members are selected without specifying 
any criteria for selection.
questions.chapter_heading: Facets of Clinical Research and Biostatistics

questions.question:
Question 2: A study on the prevalence of diabetes was conducted and the sampling method shown below 
was used. Identify the sampling method used.
questions.explanation:
In this study, the population is separated into homogenous sub-groups and from these, random 
samples are drawn. This sampling method is called stratified random sampling.

questions.question:

Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is incorrect about cluster sampling?

options.a: Clusters are created based on similarities
options.b: It is a two stage sampling
options.c: It is cheaper than most other methods
options.d: It is a method used for rapid assessment

questions.explanation:
In cluster sampling, the clusters are created randomly. On the contrary, in stratified random 
sampling, the strata or groups are created based on similarities.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which sampling method is used for assessing the immunization status of children under the 
immunization program?
questions.explanation:
Cluster sampling is the method of sampling done in immunization programs for assessing the 
immunization status of children.
questions.chapter_heading: Facets of Clinical Research and Biostatistics

questions.question:
Question 5: A research is being conducted to assess the nutritional status of the children in a particular 
district. For this purpose, 2 children are randomly selected from every school in the district. 
What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.explanation:
In the cluster sampling technique, the sub-groups of the population/ clusters are naturally 
occurring. These clusters are randomly made rather than based on any particular characteristic. 
The population of children here is naturally divided into various schools without being based on 
any characteristics.
questions.chapter_heading: Facets of Clinical Research and Biostatistics

questions.question: Question 6: In which of the following sampling techniques is design effect used?
questions.explanation:
890 
Sold by @itachibot The design effect is used in cluster sampling to allow for design structure and correlation between 
clusters. The design effect (DEFF) is used to decide the sample size needed for cluster sampling. This is 
done by calculating the difference in sampling variability to the variability expected with simple 
random sampling (SRS). It can more simply be stated as the actual sample size divided by the effective sample size (what 
you would expect if you were using SRS). For example, let’s say you were using cluster sampling. 
A DEFF of 2 means the variance is twice as large as you would expect with SRS. It also means that 
if you used cluster sampling, you’d have to use twice the sample size.

questions.question: Question 7: Simple random sampling is ideal for which of the following study groups?

options.a: A study being conducted on all vaccinated people of an area
options.b: A study on occupational exposure in all workers of the same factory
options.c: A study being conducted on prevalence of acute gastroenteritis in all school children of an area
options.d: A study on prevalence of hypertension in men aged 50-75 years in an area

questions.explanation:
Simple random sampling is ideal for a homogeneous population as the sample would be 
completely representative of the population and it would eliminate the need for systematization or 
stratification. Here, workers of the same factory form a homogeneous population. Option A: For a vaccinated population - cluster sampling Options C and D: For a heterogeneous population - stratified sampling
questions.chapter_heading: Facets of Clinical Research and Biostatistics

questions.question:
Question 8: In a study, first schools were sampled, then sections and finally students. What is this type of 
sampling known as?
questions.explanation:
Multistage sampling is the taking of samples in stages using smaller and smaller sampling units at 
each stage. It involves dividing the population into groups (or clusters). Then, one or more 
clusters are chosen at random and everyone within the chosen cluster is sampled. Snowball sampling is a type of non-random sampling preferred in case of diseases with social 
stigma (eg., alcoholism, iv drug abuse etc).
questions.chapter_heading: Facets of Clinical Research and Biostatistics

questions.question:
Question 10: In a study, subjects were assigned according to the potential factor that will influence the 
outcome of the study. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.explanation:
In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups or strata. 
From these strata, random samples are drawn. For example: If a researcher wants to conduct a research study to determine if alcohol 
consumption is a risk factor for lung cancer. He must first stratify the population into smokers 
and non-smokers because smoking is a known risk factor and also smoking is associated with 891

questions.question:
Question 15: A study was done to assess the risk factors for breast cancer in 100 females from urban cities. 
A statistical group and analysis are shown below. The values indicate the odds ratio and the 
95% confidence interval. How many risk factors may be ascertained from the statistical 
analysis of the research?
questions.explanation:
Among the factors shown in the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche, 
BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant. Hence 
these 3 factors can be ascertained as risk factors. High socioeconomic status is not a risk factor. Even though there is a positive association, it is not 
statistically significant. Any association that has a 95% confidence interval range that includes the 
value of 1.0 is considered to be non-significant. The value of 1.0 in the range means that the two 
factors may co-exist together but one is not causing the other to happen. Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of association 
between the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below: • OR > 1 indicates a positive association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence 
limits are also >1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertained 
as a risk factor. • OR = 1indicates no association. Irrespective of the odds ratio, if the lower limit of 95% CI is <1 
and the upper limit of 95% CI >1, the OR is non-significant and cannot be ascertained either as 
a protective or a risk factor. • OR < 1 indicates a negative association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidence 
limits are also <1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertained 
as a protective factor. Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question: Factor

questions.question: Question 17: What is Dixon’s Q test used for?
questions.explanation:
The Dixon’s Q test is used for identification and rejection of outliers. It is usually used in normal 
distributions.
